column3:
,>=0: number of iteration steps 
 = 0: noteration write"BTmu0","expxmu","BTerr" , "BTdat"
 =-1: no iteration , write "Btmu0" 
 =-2: noiteration , write "BTmu0","expxmu" 
 =-3: no iteration , write "BTmu0","expxmu","BTerr"

column4:
,number of half path length to be fitted out of maxpath a priori values read from "chi1m.dat" 
 0: all half path length are independent fit parameters x 
>0:maxpath half path length are x parameters 
<0: |mxpath| crystal parameter are fitted |mxpath| <= 3

,number of Debye-Waller parameters Sigma^2 to be fitted out of maxpath a priaori values read from "chi1m.dat" 
 >0: maxpath Sigma^2 are fit parameters 
 =0: all maxpath Sigma^2 are fit parameters or spring constants are fitted 
 <0: |mxspath| Sigma^2 are fit parameters
,number of C3 parameter to be fitted

column5: ,coordination numbers to be fitted ( or numbers of equivalrent paths )

column4:
,option parameter to construct the singlescattering path
=1:the scaling parameter for all paths lengths is determined by first path length 
=2: assume monolayer element A between top and bottom layer of element B 
=3:hcp crystal structure 
=4:three layers of element A with hcp crystal structure between top and bottom later of element B
=6: fits of sigma 
=7: fits of coordination number
=10:conpute paths lengths from relations given in "paths1"
,0:truncation error not used\n1:truncation error used

,input option parameter for experimental data 
=1:input of mu_exp(E) and <mu_exp(E)> data from "muexp_av.dat" 
=-1input of chi(k) data from "expchi.dat" 
=0read "expxmu.dat" file
,iteration ends for limit 10^minxq of summation after alpha optimizaton loop ( usually : -4 )

column3: ,>0:max iteration steps for alpha optimization using Turchin 2 method( usually : 3)\n<0:alpha optimization using Turchin 1 method

column4: ,number of cubic spline points for background correction in fit region\n>=3:n0bkg spline points equally distributed in fit region are set with a priori amplitudes \n=1: spline points are read from file "BTbkg0.dat"
,penalty value used in background correction is penalty = largest eigenvalue * 10^ipbkg (usually: 0)
,>0:first alpha-value for iteration \n<=0: start iteration with -imatc eigenvalues in R-space
,0: r dependence used for phase and scattering amplitudes \n1:no r dependence used
,-1:no correction terms used for half path length \n0: correction terms of cumulant expansion applied \n1:correction terms of cumulant expansion and perpendicular vibrations apllied

,-1: boots trap procedure involving crystal parameters,Sigma^2(stat),spring constants,and spin-orbit energies(for L-edges)
0: no boots trap procedure 
+1:boots trap procedure between Sigma^2(stat) and spring constants
+2: boots trap procedure with Sigma^2(stat) spring constants
,>=0:scaling factor is 0.1\n<0: when <lalph value,scaling factor is 0.5 (usually:0)
,weight of background cubic spline points
,weight of S0^2( usually : 0.0 , not fitted)
,weight of E0 ( usually : 1.0 )
,weight of half path lengths(usually : 0.02)
,weight of DW parameters( usually : 0.001 )
,weight of C3 parameters( usually : 0.0 , not fitted )
,weight of path degeneracy parameters(usually : 0.0, not fitted)
,>0: weight of structural disorder considering all atoms(usually : 0.002)\n<0:weight of structural disorder considering atoms with potential numbers 0&1 (usually : 0.002 )
,min k value of fit region \n<0: smooth cut off \n>0: sharp cut off(usually : 3.0)
,uncertainty of FEFF electron mean free path\n>0: absolute value \n<0: relative value in %(usually : 10%=-0.1)
,uncertainty of FEFF amplitude \n>0: absolute value \n<0: relative value in %(usually : 7%=-0.07)
,uncertainty of FEFF total phase\n>0: absolute value \n<0: relative value in %(usually : 0.7 Rad=0.7)
,uncertainty of half path length for y parameters\n>0: absolute value \n<0: relative value in %(usually : 0.001 angstrom)
,uncertainty of DW parameters using force-field model\n>0: absolute value \n<0: relative value in %(usually : 0.3%=-0.003)
,a priori structural disorder
,>0: absolute and k independent value of experimental uncertainty \n<0: relative (%) and k dependent value of experimental uncertainty.
,first energy value E1 of region with special uncertainty
,last energy value E2 of region with special uncertainty
,scaling factor of experimental uncertainty in energy region E1 <= E <= E2
,first energy value E4 of region with special uncertainty
,last energy value E5 of region with special uncertainty
,scaling factor of experimental uncertainty in energy region E4 <= E <= E5
,lower k value of window 1
,upper k value of window 1
,scaling factor
,lower k value of window 2
,upper k value of window 2
,scaling factor
,lower k value of window 3 (option)
,upper k value of window 3(option)
,scaling factor of experimental uncertainty(option)
,recursion order of force-field model  (usually : 8) \n<=0: force-field model not used
,option for spring constants of force-field model \n=0: read just this line\n=1: read an additional line for extra spring constants
,sample temperature in Kelvin
,first spring constant in N/m (stretching mode)
,second spring constant in N/m (stretching mode)
,third spring constant in N/m (stretching mode)
,bending mode spring constant(when used, fedf3 and delfed3 are set to zero)
,weight of fed1
,weight of fed2
,weight of fed3
,weight of fed4
,Debye temperature in Kelvin to estimate the contribution of vibrations perpendicular to path length vector and/or to use correlated Debye model
,weight of Debye temperature in fit
,first shell radius of force-field model for deformed crystal  (usually : 0.0 )
,second shell radius of force-field model for deformed crystal (usually : 0.0 )
,third shell radius of force-field model for deformed crystal (usually : 0.0 )

column5: ,max omega squared value of vibration spectrum(usually : about 4000)

column4: ,if Zi != Zj and Rij <= rsh5 then Kapper = fedf5 (stretching mode)
,weight of fed5
,if Zi = Zj and Rij <= rsh6 then Kapper = fedf6 (stretching mode)
,weight of fed6
,if Zi != Zj and Rij <= rsh7 then Kapper = fedf7 (stretching mode)
,weight of fed7
,distance between atom i and atom j for fedf5
,distance between atom i and atom j for fedf6
,distance between atom i and atom j for fedf7

column5: ,1: for mu_exp with overlaying L1,L2,L3 edges\n0: otherwise
,>0: smooth FEFF-mu_0,L1 using 5-point box-smoothin ism times when read in subroutine "xmunom"(usually: 3)\n0:don't smooth mu_0,L1

column4: ,L1 edge (k=0 value) in eV
,L2 edge (k=0 value) in eV
,L3 edge (k=0 value) in eV
,amplitude of artificial disturbance in mu_0_L1, mu_0_L2, mu_0_L3
,radius value of artificial disturbance in mu_0_L1, mu_0_L2, mu_0_L3
,radius variance of artificial disturbance in mu_0_L1, mu_0_L2, mu_0_L3
,0: no   Fourier filter used\n1: use Fourier filter on chi_exp and chi_mod in each iteration step.
,diffuseness of k window\n>0: Hanning window sill\n<0: Kaiser-Bessel window sill
,diffuseness of r window\n>0: Hanning window sill\n<0: Kaiser-Bessel window sill
,begin of k window\n=0:qwin1 = qmin
,end of k window\n=0: qwin2 = qmax
,begin of r window\n=0:rwin1 = 0
,end of r window\n=0: qwin2 = 30
,multiply chi by k^nqfft  for Fourier transformation
,compare experiment and model in r-space region
,>0: use potential number dependent path multiplicities\n=0: normal path multiplicities

column5: ,>0: modifiy initial lattice parameters\n=0:use initial lattice parameters read in "drda"

column4: ,=0: for bulk or single layer (one absorption center)\n>0:for iwtf+1 absorption centers (iwtf<3)
,lowest path number for (i+1)th absorption center
,max atom number in file ggeom1.dath of each absorption center
,scattering amplitude weight factors of each absorption center
